item.title: Street Fighter 6 Fans Canâ€™t Believe Capcom Wants Them To Pay To Watch The Finals
item.content:encoded:
The Capcom Cup started in 2013 with Super Street Fighter IV: Arcade Edition as the Japanese publisher sought to professionalize and take more direct ownership of its hit fighting franchiseâ€™s competitive scene. It expanded into multi-month tours leading up to the big finals, with all of the biggest matches streamed for free online. And itâ€™s continued that way, until now. Capcom announced this week that the 2026 finals for Street Fighter 6 will be a pay-per-view event, and fans are not happy. â€œNo one should be deprived of the opportunity to enjoy the pinnacle of Street Fighter,â€ Evo 2025 winner Saul Leonardo â€œMenaRDâ€ Mena II wrote on X in response to the news.

The two-time Capcom Cup champion hails from the Dominican Republic and noted, as many pros have, that locking esports behind a paywall particularly impacts fans from regions where the financial barriers are already higher. â€œI find it hard to accept,â€ he wrote. â€œI understand that in Japan, this is considered normal, and fortunately, the community is still able to support each other in this way. However, in many regions, including my own, there is hardly even the leeway to play this game.â€

The Capcom Cup 12 Finals will take place on March 14, followed by the Street Fighter League World Championship on March 15. Both will take place live at the RyÅgoku Kokugikan Sumo Arena in Tokyo, Japan, where front row seats will cost roughly $135. In a major break with the past, however, even virtual viewership will be ticketed this time around. The pay-per-view ticket price will be roughly $40 for both days. Anyone who doesnâ€™t want to pay will have to wait until a week later to stream the matches online for free.

The move caught many competitive Street Fighter pros by surprise. Next yearâ€™s Capcom Cup sports a $1,282,000 prize pool, unchanged from the prior year, despite the new income stream. â€œIf this decision is final, then I hope at the very least a % of the PPV earnings be used to support the prize pool to improve the payout distribution for the players,â€ Arman â€œPhenomâ€ Hanjani wrote on X.

The issue is that while Capcom funds the CC Finals, they absolutely do not pay to run all of the tournaments where people qualify for Capcom Cup. Individual TOs and communities in countries around the world operate those events. Capcom benefits from the hardwork of those TOs andâ€¦

Itâ€™s also unclear how the PPV requirement will impact the rest of the competitive sceneâ€™s content creators who traditionally co-stream events. Others have wondered why Capcom doesnâ€™t just try to extract more money through Capcom Cup-specific in-game outfits and other cosmetics. â€œI donâ€™t know why theyâ€™re not doing this anymore. I used to buy the CPT costume pack every year, everyone wins and everyone is happy,â€ wrote Adel â€œBig Birdâ€ Anouche.

Fans are equally bewildered, pointing to all of the local events that feed into the Capcom Pro Tour but arenâ€™t directly financed by the publisher. â€œI thought Capcom organized this circuit as a marketing tool for the game,â€ one wrote on Reddit. â€œMakes no sense to charge viewers to watch it. And esports is, unfortunately, still way too niche for that to be profitable.â€

While Street Fighter is massive in Japan, many are worried the move to PPV for such a big event will just end up excluding people in other parts of the world. Does Capcom care? Apparently not.

item.title: This 2.5D Love Letter To Chrono Trigger And Other JRPG Classics Couldnâ€™t Look Any More Perfect
item.content:encoded:
Will Threads of Time be the next Sea of Stars, or instead another tedious JRPG homage that emulates the classics without being able to capture what really made them tick? That was my question when it debuted during last yearâ€™s Xbox Tokyo Game Show livestream. But every time this indie game has resurfaced since, itâ€™s looked better and better. It returned to TGS 2025 with yet another trailer perfectly calibrated to play on fansâ€™ hopes and dreams for another great 16-bit homage to all-time greats like Chrono Trigger.

The turn-based RPG with beautiful pixel art and an amazing 2.5D depth of field is being made by Canada-based Riyo Games and published by Humble Games. Thereâ€™s a team of over 30 people working on it. We still donâ€™t have a release date but itâ€™s looking in better shape than some flashy projects that dazzle with trailers but fail to actually ship. I hope the team isnâ€™t biting off more than it can chew, especially amid a tough funding environment for smaller indie developers and publishers, because everything in this trailer is exactly what I want from a Chrono Trigger spiritual successor:

The time-travelling adventure spans millions of years, from a prehistoric past to a cyberpunk future. Turn-based combat takes place in a dynamic view with bespoke attack animations. Thereâ€™s an overworld map, town hubs, and NPCs to chat up. Youâ€™ll recruit characters from different eras and unlock team combos for battle. Why are you doing all this, exactly? It sounds like youâ€™re working for the Order of Time Knights to try and protect the integrity of the timeline or something. Also: cool boss fights.

Threads of Time is being developed in Unreal Engine 5 with hand-crafted 2D pixel art. I canâ€™t stress enough how great the environments and characters look. If that can hold up over an entire 10-20 hour adventure it will be an impressive achievement, especially for the indie studioâ€™s first project. 2023â€™s Sea of Stars was the last game to pull this trick off, selling like hotcakes and winning nods at The Game Awards that year (DLC released earlier this year). Before that, there was 2021â€™s incredible-looking Eastward. I hope Threads of Time can deliver something equally special in the next year or two. Itâ€™s currently only confirmed for PC and Xbox.
